CE Documentation Library

CE Documentation Library

The CE Documentation Library lists all available manuals that serve as
references on the use of the Customer Enterprise system. The documents are
categorized into three groups: Core System Manuals, CE Utility Reference
Manuals, and Installation Guides.

>   Core System Manuals

>   The CE core system manuals provide information on the setup and
>   configuration of various CE parameters, as well as the implementation of
>   supplementary functionalities supported by the system.

Archiving and Recovery

This manual is a reference to the Archive and Recovery functionality of the CE
system. Discussions include the required parameter settings for configuring the
relevant functions, as well as examples of how this functionality is used in
transaction processes.

Building a Product

This manual is a reference to the process of building a product in CE. It
provides step-by-step procedures on how to create a basic CE module, transaction
function, and product setting; configure parameters; and attach components to
generate a working business product.

Data Objects

This manual serves as a reference for creating and utilizing data objects in the
CE system. The discussions provide details on how to build data object templates
and data object entities, and how to attach these to the transaction function
screen.

Frequently Asked Questions

This document addresses commonly-asked questions on the Customer Enterprise
system. Issues on the browser-side (transaction processing), CE Utility,
Security Module, and database, among others, are addressed in the discussions.

Interfacing CE with CS Eximbills

This document discusses the process of interfacing CE with the CS Eximbills
(CSX) back office system. Employing the MQ, FTP, and TCP/IP communication
protocols, the interface process using the XML format is detailed in this
document.

Interfacing CE with Eximbills Enterprise

This document discusses the process of interfacing CE with the Eximbills
Enterprise (EE) back office system. Employing the MQ protocol, the interface
process for the transfer of data between CE and EE using the XML format is
detailed in this document.

Log Settings

This manual provides details on CE logs as well as general instructions on log
configuration in CE. This is especially written for the users who are in charge
of maintaining the CE system.

Look and Feel

This manual is a reference guide on designing the CE user interface (i.e., the
look and feel of the system). Divided into two parts, the manual provides
instructions on creating a) the basic L&F style of CE; and b) the CE L&F style
that incorporates widgets.

Multi-Entity

This manual is a reference on implementing the Multi-Entity functionality of the
CE system. Discussions cover the implementation and application of CE
multi-entity.

Multi-Language

This manual discusses the procedures required in setting up the Multi-Language
functionality of CE as it is run by Administrator- and Operator-type users.
Furthermore, the configuration of certain system and browser elements as well as
the setup of related system parameters is explained in step-by-step procedures.

Reports

This manual is a comprehensive reference guide on the requirements and processes
involved in building business products and functions that generate online
reports and documents.

Security and System Maintenance Functions

This manual is a comprehensive guide on the security and system maintenance of
the CE system. As such, it includes detailed instructions for company and
company function management, and user and user function management. Maintenance
of key functionalities such as authorization rules, reference numbers, and other
services is covered as well. In addition, this document discusses the security
concepts in CE to assist users assigned with access rights to the CE Security
Module.

Standing Data Functions

This document discusses the functions for the CE standing data that are
maintained by operators (e.g., parties, clauses). It includes sections for each
function, starting with a brief description of the function, followed by the
function input when necessary, and the procedure steps.

Supplementary Functions

This manual is a reference for the CE Utility operator user in configuring
parameter, JSP, and transaction function settings to define special or
supplementary CE functionalities such as uploading images, sending images and
forms to the back-office system, and sending notifications via e-mail, SMS, and
widgets.

System Administration Functions

This manual is a reference for the default Super Administrator user of the CE
Utility in the configuration and maintenance of the CE environment. It discusses
in detail user management and parameter management.

System Reference

This document serves as a quick reference to the following elements that are
used when configuring specific parameters in the CE Utility: global system
parameters, system parameters, components, XML Generator items, server side
system methods, system JS methods, and APIs.

>   CE Utility Reference Manuals

>   The CE Utility Reference set of manuals is a guide on the use of the
>   Customer Enterprise Utility Workbench, or simply CE Utility. This reference
>   provides details on every function or feature in the CE Utility and includes
>   instructions and step-by-step procedures on how to operate or use the
>   function in relation to operating and maintaining the CE system and
>   processing a business transaction.

>   A manual is provided for each function group of the CE Utility:

-   *CE Utility Reference: User Manager Functions*, for the functions that
    belong to the User Manage function group of the CE Utility when accessed by
    an Administrator or Operator user

-   *CE Utility Reference: Parameter Manager Functions*, for the functions that
    belong to the Parameter Manage function group of the CE Utility when
    accessed by an Administrator or Operator user

-   *CE Utility Reference: System Functions*, for the functions that belong to
    the System Function group of the CE Utility.

-   *CE Utility Reference: Transaction Functions*, for the functions that belong
    to the Transaction Function group of the CE Utility.

-   *CE Utility Reference: Product Functions*, for the functions that belong to
    the Product Function group of the CE Utility.

-   *CE Utility Reference: Maintenance Functions*, for the functions that belong
    to the Maintenance function group of the CE Utility.

    Installation Guides

    The CE installation guides are references on the installation and setup
    processes of the CE system on different application servers and databases.

Installation Guide WAS 9.0 - Oracle 19c

This is a reference for installing the CE system on WebSphere Application Server
Version 9.0.5.6, with an Oracle 19c database. This includes detailed
instructions on configuring the components that are required to successfully run
CE.

Introduction

-   system overview

System Overview

CE Look and Feel, or CE L&F, pertains to the CE user interface that is designed
when the different elements that make up a functional transaction page are put
together based on a desired output.

Generally, CE supports two types of L&F: a basic style, and one that supports
the Widget functionality.

Manual Overview

>   **Purpose**

>   This manual serves as a guide on designing the CE user interface (i.e., the
>   look and feel of the system). It provides instructions on:

-   Creating the basic look and feel style of CE

-   Creating CE look and feel style that incorporates widgets

    This document is written with the assumption that:

-   The CE environment has already been successfully installed; and

-   The reader has sufficient knowledge on building a CE product and running the
    CE Utility functions

-   The reader has sufficient knowledge on the following programming languages
    and software, which are used in designing the L&F of the CE system:

-   HTML

-   CSS

-   JavaScript

-   Cross-browser scripting (CE V3 supports IE 6+ and Firefox versions higher
    than 2.0)

-   DreamWeaver

>   **Audience**

>   This manual is a reference specifically for, but not limited to, the
>   following users:

-   Consultants responsible for creating the transaction screens and maintaining
    the system look and feel.

    **Prerequisites**

-   Suggested titles before reading this manual: *CE Building a Product and* *CE
    Utility References*

>   version. Unless otherwise specified, the overall functionality is the same
>   when recreated in the current version.

Running the CE Utility

The Customer Enterprise Utility Workbench, or CE Utility, is the main tool for
building parameters in CE.

>   Preparing the CE Utility Files

>   Along with the installation files, the CE Utility folder is provided with
>   every CE system release. Prior to using the CE Utility, do the following:

1.  Copy the CE Utility folder to the local drive.

2.  Define the required environment variables.

3.  Map the CE directories (e.g., CEWeb.war and CE_PARA) to the network drive.

| ![](media/f59fb80c7cdcc11ee082a8737fd07b5c.png) |
|-------------------------------------------------|

**Figure 2. 1 CE Utility Folder**

>   **![note](media/dbcc08f02d55bf00c6d727f95e13c20c.png)NOTE:**

1.  The default drives defined in the GEN_XML_ROOTPATH and GEN_WEB_ROOTPATH
    system parameters are O:\\ and P:\\ respectively. These drives, if currently
    not existing, may be created through a batch file. While O:\\ and P:\\are
    the default drives for CE, these may be set to any other preferred drive
    available in the network.

2.  To enable users to use the CE Utility on their own local machines as clients
    connecting to the CE server: 1) Install the Java Development Kit (JDK)
    program; 2) Copy the CE Utility folder; 3) Create the JAVA_HOME environment
    variable, which must point to this directory: [Java Home]\\[Installed JDK].

3.  For more details on setting up the CE environment, refer to the CE
    installation guides*.*

4.  For details on the CE Utility functions, refer to the *CE Utility Reference*
    manuals.

| **Batch File for Creating the CE Drives** The batch file for creating drives contains the following commands:  subst O: /d subst P: /d subst O: C:"\\Program Files\\IBM\\WebSphere\\AppServer\\profiles\\AppSrv01\\installedApps\\DOCS-CEV336Node01Cell\\CE.ear\\CE_PARA" subst P: C:"\\Program Files\\IBM\\WebSphere\\AppServer\\profiles\\AppSrv01\\installedApps\\DOCS-CEV336Node01Cell\\CE.ear\\CEWeb.war"   ![](media/1aac69fcddde2c3b654568c7a6d069cd.png)  |
|-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|

>   CE Utility Functions

>   The functions that may be accessed for setting up parameters are organized
>   together into several function groups. The current available function groups
>   and their corresponding functions in the CE Utility are as follows:

**User Manager Function Group**

>   This function group is comprised of functions used for creating,
>   configuring, and exporting Bank-Country group settings; creating new users;
>   and configuring data sources. These functions are:

-   Business Unit Config

-   DataSource Manage

-   Import/Export Business Unit

-   User Manage

**Parameter Manage Function Group**

>   This function group consists of functions used for maintaining system-wide
>   parameters and components. These functions are:

-   AP Server

-   Component Manage

-   Language Configuration

-   System Parameter

-   System Parameters

**System Function Group**

>   This function group consists of functions used for maintaining and
>   facilitating system-wide tasks, operations, and settings. These functions
>   are:

-   Image Type Maintain

-   Output Device

-   Queue Manager

-   STP Setting

-   Time Zone

**Transaction Function Group**

>   This function group is comprised of functions used for defining the actual
>   business parameters of transaction functions. These facilitate the
>   maintenance and processes of the business transaction modules. These
>   functions are:

-   Amount/Rate Format

-   Batch Manage

-   Clause

-   DO Get Data

-   Export Setting

-   Form

-   GAPIs Setting

-   Get Data

-   Image Control

-   Message Broker Setting

-   Module & Event

-   Report Template

-   STPs Mapping

-   Sub Tasks

-   SWIFT Config

-   System Maintain

-   Transaction Function

-   Transfer To

-   TSU Mapping

-   Upload Message Setting

-   Web Service Setting

-   Widget Maintain

**Product Function Group**

>   This function group consists of functions that are used for creating and
>   configuring the products to be accessed and used by the customers or
>   end-users. These functions are:

-   Fields Select

-   Inbox

-   Product Authorize

-   Product Authorize Setting

-   Product Catalog

-   Product Function Setting

-   Product Item

**Maintenance Function Group**

>   This function group is comprised of functions used for facilitating the
>   maintenance of data from CE tables, including fields and error settings.
>   These functions are:

-   DB Dictionary

-   Error Handling

-   Error Message Config (CE)

-   Field Conversion

-   Multi Language

-   Page Dictionary

-   XML Generator

Generating the XML Parameter Files

The created parameters and business logic are stored in the database as Meta
data. For this Meta data to be accessible to the application server (AP) and the
web server, it has to be converted to XML – the format used for the
communication between the client and the server.

The XML files are generated through the XML Generator function of the
Maintenance function group in the CE Utility. In most cases, the XML Generator
function must be run when a parameter is created or modified using the functions
discussed in this document.

| **Do the following . .** **.** |
|--------------------------------|

| 1. Log on CE Utility as an Administrator or Operator user with rights to the XML Generator function.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                |   | ![](media/57e81c050aebcc5769d11f355b42184f.png) |
|-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|---|-------------------------------------------------|
|                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     |   |                                                 |
| 2. The CE Utility window is displayed. Run the XML Generator function from the Maintenance function group. Alternatively, click on the XML Generator button in the function toolbar.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                |   | ![](media/f23db4a3687be895237749b27f8121b2.png) |
|                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     |   |                                                 |
| 3. The XML Generator function window is displayed. When there are newly defined or modified parameters, the Meta Data to XML window is also displayed. It lists these parameters for easy selection. In this case, the parameter can be selected from this window and the Apply button clicked. Afterwards, proceed to Step 5. Alternatively, the Meta data or parameter can be manually selected from the main XML Generator window. In this case, click on the Close button of the Meta Data to XML window and proceed to Step 4. |   | ![](media/a8113a7c557ca4d3c46f3528ac7e4641.png) |

| 4. Double-click on the relevant parameter type from the XML Generator window.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       |   | ![](media/058c2783e605566737b7a9362338cac4.png) |

If the configuration window is displayed, indicate the exact or any additional setting required to generate the relevant XML files. When the specifications are defined click on the Save button                                                                                                                                                                                |   | ![](media/43bce304e0820d2a2bb557e6bba10753.png) |
|                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     |   |                                                 |
| 6. A message is displayed confirming if the XML files are to be generated on the system path.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       |   | ![](media/696ee71d600c332075f97428af08a14d.png) |

Building a Product

When building a product in the CE Utility, a few prerequisites are required to
be met to make sure that modules or products are built in accordance with the
bank’s requirements. One step is the GAP analysis which involves an evaluation
of transaction requirements, based on the process flow (e.g., fields, clauses,
forms, and interfaces). These are required for identifying the fields required
for anticipating the required output. When the analysis has been completed, the
project team can now begin the process of building a product for the bank’s
customers.

The following are steps in building a product:

1.  **Access the CE Utility**. To access the CE Utility for building parameters,
    an Operator user must be created by an Administrator user. This is set up
    through the User Manager function in the User Manage function group.

2.  **Set up the module and events**. This involves naming the module and the
    projected events that manage the transaction flow within the module. This is
    set up in the Module and Event function in CE Utility.

3.  **Set up the transaction tables.** This involves creating the tables in the
    DB Dictionary function in CE Utility. There can be different types of tables
    but only three are mandatory for a CE module: master, ledger, and event.

    ![note](media/dbcc08f02d55bf00c6d727f95e13c20c.png)NOTE: It is possible to
    create tables directly into the database by running SQL scripts in the
    database. In this case, tables can be created before modules and events. It
    is recommended, however, to use the DB Dictionary for creating tables.

4.  **Add fields to the transaction table**. Fields must be added to a
    transaction table and field properties defined for the processing and
    storage of data. These can be done through the DB Dictionary function in CE
    Utility.

5.  **Set up the transaction functions**. This involves creating the functions
    that correspond to actual business transaction processes. This is done
    through Transaction Function in the Transaction Function group.

6.  **Set up the transaction parameters**. This involves designing the
    transaction screen, defining attribute and catalog settings, and attaching
    these parameters to the transaction function. These can be done through
    Transaction Function in CE Utility.

7.  **Create the product.** The product is the actual functionality accessed and
    run by the end-user. This process of creating a product involves setting up
    the product group, product, and product function, and defining product
    catalog settings.

8.  **Define authorization rules**. Authorization rules are set to further
    define or set limits for authorizing transactions.

9.  **Calculation.** This involves configuring the transaction JS files and
    defining calculation functions using available system methods. There are
    three JS files that have to be configured: the Module Base JS file, Event JS
    file, and Function JS file.

10. **Define the settings for the transaction input.** Certain functions may be
    added to aid in the input of data into the transaction. The CE Utility
    provides options for setting up field conversion rules, lookup buttons,
    customer reference numbers, clauses, dropdown lists, and data objects for
    this purpose.

11. **Define the settings for the transaction output.** Some business
    transactions involve output generation (i.e., Forms). To make this option
    available, certain settings must be configured using the functions from the
    Transaction Function group in CE Utility.

12. **Define the security settings in the CE browser.** The products and
    functions created are assigned to an end-user through the browser-side
    Security and System Maintenance functions.

    ![note](media/dbcc08f02d55bf00c6d727f95e13c20c.png)NOTE: The browser-side
    security and system maintenance functions of CE are often collectively
    called the Security Module.

13. **Add the Inbox functionality.** Another way of accessing a product or a
    transaction for further processing is through the Customer Inbox. This can
    be set up through the Inbox function in CE Utility.

>   ![note](media/dbcc08f02d55bf00c6d727f95e13c20c.png)NOTE: For more details on
>   configuring different parameters in CE, refer to the *CE Utility Reference*
>   manuals*.*

Resetting the Password

The CE logon page includes the I Forgot My Password link, which allows the
system to send a new password to the user through e-mail. To use this link:

| Do the following . . .  |
|-------------------------|

| 1. Click on the I Forgot My Password link.                                                                                                                                                             |   | ![](media/01311b0777195b7afa2adeb2b37ce871.png)         |
|--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|---|---------------------------------------------------------|
|                                                                                                                                                                                                        |   |                                                         |
| 2. The Forgotten Password page is displayed.                                                                                                                                                           |   | ![](media/7a5841c9d899d677485fa8687e3a9844.png)         |
|                                                                                                                                                                                                        |   |                                                         |
| Specify the e-mail address to which the password reset link is to be sent. Click on the Continue button.                                                                                               |   | ![tmp7211](media/07e29d59c94bec7d8d90cfb5e3cc7417.jpeg) |
|                                                                                                                                                                                                        |   |                                                         |
| 3. If only one user uses the specified e-mail address, the system proceeds to the next step. If multiple users use the e-mail address:  The Login ID field is displayed. Select the relevant login Id. |   | ![tmp7215](media/2103a6d0d990692f2c0514d273cc5a15.jpeg) |
|                                                                                                                                                                                                        |   |                                                         |
| Click on the Confirm button.                                                                                                                                                                           |   | ![tmp7221](media/a7c5cabd03a5223c7231984322845ff9.jpeg) |
|                                                                                                                                                                                                        |   |                                                         |
| 4. A message is displayed confirming that an e-mail is sent to the specified e-mail address. This e-mail contains the link that enables the user to reset the password.                                |   | ![tmp7223](media/6148befa992f07258cafcc0ae7817c2d.jpeg) |

>   ![](media/484376c5e28e6fece5e429cfb2f6d578.gif)NOTE: The password of the CE
>   user must conform to the following rules:

1.  It must be at least 8-characters long.

2.  It must contain an uppercase character, a lowercase character, and a digit.

3.  It must not contain any special characters.

4.  It must not contain more than three consecutive digits or more than three
    consecutive identical characters.

5.  It must not contain the user account or name.

6.  It must not be the same as recently used passwords

Inbox

The Inbox shows the statistics or count for transaction statuses. It is also
another way to access business transactions. Inbox elements are defined in the
CE Utility.

The system generates a JavaScript data array to create the inbox table on the CE
page: TOTALARRAY. This data array is included in the SYS_FRAME IFrame.

The default system methods for creating the inbox table are in this file –

>   [WEB SERVER DRIVE]\\SYS_JS\\SYS_inbox.js

The default inbox layout is defined in –

>   [WEB SERVER DRIVE]\\SYS_LF_JS\\LF_SYS_inbox.js

To customize the inbox, add the related JavaScript methods in this file to
control the data array –

>   [WEB SERVER DRIVE]\\JS\\Inbox.js

Main Function Pages

The three types of main function pages are transaction screens, standing data
screens, and security screens.

>   Transaction Screens

>   Transaction Page

>   attached to a product, which can be a product of the bank or an additional
>   banking service. The transaction module is in charge of managing the
>   processing flows of a transaction. Data input for transactions is
>   facilitated through the fields in this page.

>   The transaction pages that are retrieved during runtime are placed in this
>   path in the Web folder –

(Another way is through the inbox.)

The L&F of the main menu varies according to the bank requirements.

| ![](media/b4346f6ff3719121be31e0dc9e284a92.png) Figure 4. 1 Example 1 | ![](media/08e106d3a2faada4e0758e8979c69e3f.png) Figure 4. 2 Example 2 |

Creating the Main Menu

The overall functionality of the main menu is defined in these JS files.

| **JS File**                  | **Description**                                                  |
|------------------------------|------------------------------------------------------------------|
| \\SYS_JS\\ SYS_menu.js       | This contains the codes for building or designing the main menu. |
| \\SYS_JS\\ SYS_menu_event.js | This contains the codes running the functions in the main menu.  |

To change the L&F of the main menu:

1.  Create a standalone JS file for building the main menu as required.

2.  Declare this standalone JS file in the transaction screens. Make sure that
    the SYS_menu.js file is removed from the codes

3.  Declare the SYS_menu_event.js file in all the transaction screens or in the
    Common.jsp file:

Generating the Main Menu

The Function Access Permission (FAP) of the CE user, assigned in the Security
Module, determines the type of menu to be created for the user. Specifically, a
JavaScript data array is generated.

Declare \<CETAGS:GetMenuArray/\> files located in the following directory:

>   [WEB SERVER DRIVE]\\ Templates

The data array, strArray, contains the following parameters:

| **Array Index** |  **Parameter**       | Description                                                                                                                                              | Example                             |
|-----------------|----------------------|----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|-------------------------------------|
| 0               | Module               | This refers to the 4-character module name.                                                                                                              | SECU                                |
| 1               | Product Id           | This refers to the product Id.                                                                                                                           | P06031300000                        |
| 2               | Product Name         | This refers to the product name.                                                                                                                         | Authorization User Rule by Function |
| 3               | Function Id          | This refers to the function Id.                                                                                                                          | F05030700553                        |
| 4               | Function name        | This refers to the function name.                                                                                                                        | Add Auth User Rule by Func          |
| 5               | Item Id              | This refers to the item Id.                                                                                                                              | New                                 |
| 6               | Item Name            | This refers to the item name.                                                                                                                            | New                                 |
| 7               | Product Type         | This refers to the product type – ‘S’ (Security) or ‘T’ (Transaction).                                                                                   |                                     |
| 8               | New/Cata             | This refers to the type of screen produced when a product is clicked: a new (initiation) screen or a catalog screen. This is now supported in CE V2.1.0. |                                     |
| 9               | Catalog Number       | This refers to the number of catalogs in the catalog screen. As this is currently not supported in CE V2.1.0, the value is: 1.                           |                                     |
| 10              | Module Description   | This refers to the description of the module.                                                                                                            | Security Module                     |
| 11              | Product Description  | This refers to the description of the product.                                                                                                           | Operator Class Maintain             |
| 12              | Function Description | This refers to the description of the function.                                                                                                          | Add Operator Class                  |

The strArray data array generated follows this format:

[“[MODULE]”, “[PRODUCT ID]”, “[PRODUCT NAME]”, “[FUNCTION ID]”, “[FUNCTION
NAME]”, “[ITEM ID]”, “[ITEM NAME]”, “[PRODUCT TYPE]”, “[NEW/CATA]”, “[CATALOG
NUMBER]”. “[MODULE DESCRIPTION]”, “[PRODUCT DESCRIPTION]”]

**EXAMPLE**:

["IMLC","P08071500000","Import Letters of Credit","F05030700829","Apply for
Import LC","New","New","T","new","1","Import Letters of Credit","Import Letters
of Credit","Apply for Import LC"]

| ![](media/500a9d6d244f3de51e3d8234a63ce60f.png) |
|-------------------------------------------------|

Figure 4. 4 Example of an HTML Source Code

This JavaScript file contains the commands for creating the main menu, and may
be modified to produce different menu styles: [WEB SERVER
DRIVE]\\JS\\MainMenu.js. Refer also to [Chapter Eight \>
MainMenu.js](#Mainmenujs_CH8) discussion for sample content of the MainMenu.js
file.

Running a Menu Function

When a user selects a function from the main menu, the onClick() event of the
main menu is executed. Depending on the project involved, either of the
following functions has to be called in order to execute this event:

-   funcItemClick (modDesc, pdtID, funcID, itemID, modName)

-   \_funcItemClick(sSelectedFuncId)

These methods are defined in the following file –

>   [WEB SERVER DRIVE]\\SYS_JS\\SYS_menu_event.js

| ![](media/c4a85e9b2ac10c638b6bb27500ef0fd4.png) |
|-------------------------------------------------|

System CSS Classes

System CSS Classes

For system purposes such as field validation and date formatting, system CSS
classes are provided. These CSS classes are located in the following directory:
[WEB SERVER DIRECTORY]/theme

Each of the fields in the JSP screen, including hidden fields, must be assigned
a valid system CSS class, the naming rule of the which is: [DATA TYPE]_[FIELD
TYPE].

The following table lists the available system CSS classes.

| **Class Name** | **Description**           | Example                 |
|----------------|---------------------------|-------------------------|
| AMT\_M         | Mandatory amount field    | LC Amount               |
| AMT\_O         | Optional amount field     | Finance Amount          |
| AMT\_P         | Protected amount field    | LC Balance              |
| INT\_M         | Mandatory integer field   | Tenor Days              |
| INT\_O         | Optional integer field    | Positive Tolerance      |
| INT_P          | Protected integer field   | Amendment No            |
| FLOAT_M        | Mandatory float field     | Interest Rate           |
| FLOAT_O        | Optional float field      | Interest Rate           |
| FLOAT_P        | Protected float field     | Interest Rate           |
| CHAR\_M        | Mandatory character field | Beneficiary Name        |
| CHAR\_O        | Optional character field  | Beneficiary ID          |
| CHAR\_P        | Protected character field | Collection Reference No |
| DATE_M         | Mandatory date field      | Expiry Date             |
| DATE_O         | Optional date field       | Tenor Start Date        |
| DATE_P         | Protected date field      | Issued Date             |
| TIME_M         | Mandatory time field      | Transaction Time        |
| TIME_O         | Optional time field       | Registration Time       |
| TIME_P         | Protected time field      | Login Time              |

| ![](media/37e3200bacb9618fb6201fe13ea85f9a.png)  |
|--------------------------------------------------|

Figure 5. 1 Example of a CSS File

project-designed CSS files can also be used. These are also saved in the same
directory where the system CSS files are located.

FTL Files

FTL Files

Freemarker Template (FTL) files are templates that can be embedded into the JSP
file. These are used to generate text and define the look and feel of pages in a
transaction screen.

By modifying the related FTL files, the L&F of screens that are generated by CE
tags such as GetTranCata can be defined or changed. All FTL files are stored in
the following directories:

-   [WEB SERVVER DRIVE]\\WEB-INF\\FTL

-   [WEB SERVVER DRIVE]\\Templates\\FTL

The following are the available FTL files that can be modified according to
business or functional requirements:

(Start of Code)

/\*\*

\* for generating main menu

\*/

/\*\*

\* Data array in strArray

\* [0 module][1 product id][2 name(?)][3 function id][4 function name][5 item
id]

\* [6 item name][7 product type(S or T)][8 new type][9 cata num][10 module
description]

\* [11 product description] [12 function description]

\*/

//Global variables

var nNoOfFuncs = 0; // number of functions

var sSelectedProdId = ""; //Selected product id

var sSelectedFuncId = ""; //Selected function id

/\*\*

\* call showMainMenu() in the end of JSP

\*/

function showMainMenu(){

try {

if (!window.strArray) {

showMsg("The FAP is invalid.", "There was a problem login in.");

return;

}

//PRODUCT_ID is in catalog and trx

if (window.PRODUCT_ID && window.PRODUCT_ID.length \> 0) {

sSelectedProdId = PRODUCT_ID;

}

//get function id for catalog and transaction screen

if (window.selFuncDesc && window.selFuncDesc.length \> 0 && window.selFuncDesc
!= "null" && window.PRODUCT_ID) {

sSelectedFuncId = getFuncIdByFuncDesc(selFuncDesc)

}

var b = document.getElementById("ProdMenu");

if(b){ genMainMenu(b)}

}

catch (a) {

showExcpt("MainMenu", a)

}

}

var hiddenProdArray=[];

var hiddenFuncArray=[];

function inHiddenProdArray(b){

for(var a=0;a\<hiddenProdArray.length;a++){

if(b==hiddenProdArray[a])

{return true}}return false}

function inHiddenFuncArray(d,e){

for(var b=0;b\<hiddenFuncArray.length;b++)

{if(d==hiddenFuncArray[b][0])

{var c=hiddenFuncArray[b][1];

for(var a=0;a\<c.length;a++){if(e==c[a])

{return true}}}}return false

}

function genMainMenu(b){

try {

if (!window.strArray) {

showMsg("The FAP is invalid.", "There was a problem login in.");

return;

}

//init variable

if (LOGIN_NAME && LOGIN_NAME == "A") {

isSEC = true;

}

else {

isSEC = false;

}

nNoOfFuncs = strArray.length;

genProdTable(b);

}

catch (a) {

showExcpt("MainMenu", a);

}

}

/\*\*

\* Generate product table

\*

\*/

function genProdTable(f){

try {

//drop product menu table

if (f.firstChild) {

f.removeChild(f.firstChild);

}

//create product menu table and append to product menu table cell

var b = document.createElement("table");

b.setAttribute("id", "ProdMenuTable");

b.setAttribute("cellspacing", "0");

b.setAttribute("cellpadding", "0");

b.className = "ProdItem";

f.appendChild(b);

//create product menu table tbody

var d = document.createElement("tbody");

d.setAttribute("id", "ProdMenuTableBody");

b.appendChild(d);

var a = f.id;

//create product rows in product menu table

genProdRow(d, a)

}

catch (c) {

showExcpt("MainMenu", c);

}

}

/\*\*

\* Generate product rows

\*/

function genProdRow(d, k){

try {

var a = new Array();

var p = new Array();

for (var h = 0; h \< nNoOfFuncs; h++) {

var r = strArray[h][1];

var g = strArray[h][11];

if (!p.in_array(g)) {

a.push(r);

p.push(g);

}

}

//add product row

var c = p.length;

for (var f = 0; f \< c; f++) {

if(inHiddenProdArray(a[f])){continue}

var q = document.createElement("tr");

var b = "row_" + a[f];

q.setAttribute("id", b);

var l = document.createElement("td");

var o = "cell_" + a[f];

l.setAttribute("id", o);

var m = document.createElement("a");

m.setAttribute("id", a[f]);

m.setAttribute("pid", k);

m.href = "\#";

//set class to SelectedProdLink

if (a[f] == sSelectedProdId) {

m.className = "SelectedProdLink"

}

else {

m.className = "ProdLink"

}

m.innerHTML = p[f];

m.onclick = getProdIdOnClick;

l.appendChild(m);

q.appendChild(l);

d.appendChild(q);

//show selected product functions

if (sSelectedProdId.length \> 0 && sSelectedProdId == a[f]) {

genProdFunc(d, sSelectedProdId);

}

}

}

catch (e) {

showExcpt("MainMenu", e)

}

}

/\*\*

\* Generate produc functions table

\*/

function genProdFunc(k, h){

try {

var m = h;

var c = new Array();

//function id under this product

for (var g = 0; g \< nNoOfFuncs; g++) {

if (strArray[g][1] == m) {

var l = strArray[g][3];

c.push(l)

}

}

var b = document.createElement("tr");

k.appendChild(b);

var d = document.createElement("td");

d.setAttribute("id", "selectedSubMenu");

d.style.paddingRight = "0px";

d.style.paddingLeft = "0px";

d.style.paddingBottom = "0px";

d.style.paddingTop = "0px";

b.appendChild(d);

//product function table

var f = document.createElement("table");

f.setAttribute("id", "ProdFuncTable");

function genFuncRow(s, b, a){

try {

var l= new Array();

var c = new Array();

//get func desc under this product

for (var g = 0; g \< nNoOfFuncs; g++) {

var h = strArray[g][5];

var q = strArray[g][12];

if (strArray[i][1] == s) {

l.push(h);

c.push(q);

}

}

//add product row

var o = b.length;

for (var f = 0; f \< o; f++) {

>   if(inHiddenFuncArray(s,b[f])){continue}

var p = document.createElement("tr");

var n = "funcrow_" + b[f];

p.setAttribute("id", n);

var d = document.createElement("td");

var r = "funccell_" + b[f];

d.style.paddingRight = "0px";

d.style.paddingLeft = "14px";

d.setAttribute("id", r);

var k = document.createElement("a");

k.setAttribute("id", b[f]);

k.href = "\#";

if (b[f] == sSelectedFuncId) {

k.className = "SelectedFuncLink"

}

else {

k.className = "FuncLink"

}

k.innerHTML = c[f];

k.onclick = getFuncIdOnClick;

d.appendChild(k);

p.appendChild(d);

a.appendChild(p);

}

}

catch (m) {

showExcpt("MainMenu", m)

}

}

function getProdIdOnClick(c){

try {

if (sSelectedProdId == a) {

var f = document.getElementById("selectedSubMenu");

var b = f.style.display;

if ("none" == b) {

f.style.display = "block"

else {

}

else {

sSelectedProdId = a;

var d = i.getAttribute("pid");

genProdTable(document.getElementById(d))

}

}

catch (h) {

function getFuncIdOnClick(a){

\_funcItemClick(sSelectedFuncId)

PART II:   
CE WIDGET FRAMEWORK

Introduction to CE Widgets

-   Widget Overview and Prerequisites

-   The Initial CE Landing Page with widgets

-   General Widget Parameter Settings

Widget Overview and Prerequisites

Widgets

A widget is a small application that can be installed and run within a web page
by an end-user. Occupying only a minor portion of a web page, a widget performs
a basic functionality. Widgets often take the form of on-screen programs such as
calculators and event countdowns.

In CE Version 3.0 and higher, 12 types of widgets are supported. These standard
(native) widgets are:

-   Calculator

-   Calendar Events

-   Criteria Search

-   Dashboard

-   Exchange Rate

-   Main Menu

-   Notice

-   Quick Access

-   Recent Functions

-   Summary

-   Upload Message

-   Welcome

-   Statistics

>   **![](media/dbcc08f02d55bf00c6d727f95e13c20c.png)NOTE:** The Notice widget
>   is formerly called Notification widget in versions prior to CE Version
>   3.2.0.

With this Widget functionality in CE:

-   The consultant or developer can:

-   import a Widget list into the CE application

-   design the look and feel of the CE application with widgets

-   The end-user can customize the tabs and widgets of the CE application. The
    specific attributes of a widget can be modified as well.

-   Security FAP and DAP checks are inherited from the current CE entitlements.

-   A project team can build its own special widgets and plug it into this
    framework.

>   **![](media/dbcc08f02d55bf00c6d727f95e13c20c.png)NOTE:** CSWidgets refers to
>   the widget standard of China Systems.

>   The CSWidgets widget standard supports most of the features in JSR168 and
>   JSR286. If it is required to show the CE widgets in the bank's portlet
>   server, major services for the bank's portlet server can be provided.
>   Moreover, the CSWidgets standard matches the JSR168 and JSR286 portlet
>   standards.

| ![](media/dc9056f75561ee881a8dfbf3f978c465.png) |
|-------------------------------------------------|

Figure 9. 1 Example: CE Design Layout with Widgets

Prerequisites

To support widgets on the CE landing page, including the Personalize link that
is used for customizing the tabs and widgets, modify the following file:

[PARAMETER DRIVE]\\CE_SYS\\SYST\\sys_screens.xml

-   Change the TrxMainMenu setting:

| **From**                                                                                                                                                                                                 |
|----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
|  \<SCREEN\>  \<ALIAS\>TrxMainMenu\</ALIAS\>  \<DESC\>Trx main menu\</DESC\>  *\<JSPFILE\>../screen/SYS_main_menu.jsp\</JSPFILE\>*  *\<TMPLFILE\>../Templates/SYS_Template.jsp\</TMPLFILE\>* \</SCREEN\>  |
| **To**                                                                                                                                                                                                   |
|  \<SCREEN\>  \<ALIAS\>TrxMainMenu\</ALIAS\>  \<DESC\>Trx main menu\</DESC\>  *\<JSPFILE\>../screen/widgetMain.jsp\</JSPFILE\>*  *\<TMPLFILE\>../Templates/WGT_Template.jsp\</TMPLFILE\>* \</SCREEN\>     |

-   

-   Add this setting:

|  \<SCREEN\>  \<ALIAS\>CustomizeWidget\</ALIAS\>  \<DESC\>Customize Widget\</DESC\>  \<JSPFILE\>../screen/widgetCust.jsp\</JSPFILE\>  \<TMPLFILE\>../Templates/WGT_Template.jsp\</TMPLFILE\> \</SCREEN\> |
|---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|

After making these modifications, restart the application server.

>   Basic CE Widget Operations

>   With the initial and default widget settings in CE, the end-user can perform
>   the following on the CE landing page:

-   Display specific widgets

-   Remove specific widgets

-   Add tabs

>   These are configured through the Personalize page of the system.

>   **![](media/dbcc08f02d55bf00c6d727f95e13c20c.png)NOTE:** The Personalize
>   page is also referred to as the Page Builder.

>   Displaying Widgets

>   The CE landing page may contain multiple tabs. The layout of a tab can
>   support:

-   A maximum of three columns; and

-   Each column can contain as many widget instances as required.

    By default, the system provides the Home tab with the Main Menu and Welcome
    widget instances.

>   **![](media/dbcc08f02d55bf00c6d727f95e13c20c.png)NOTE:** Widgets of the same
>   type are called instances of that widget.

>   To add a widget on the relevant tab:

As long as the widget name is enabled, then it can be added multiple times to the current tab: multiple instances of this widget can be displayed and utilized on that tab.  **EXAMPLE:**  Given that: 1) There are two tabs: Home and Test; 2) The Welcome widget has been defined to be utilized only once; 3) The Main Menu widget has been defined to be utilized multiple times; and 4) The Home tab already contains a Main Menu widget instance. >   Adjusting Widget Layouts

>   The CE system supports a maximum of 4 widget columns.

>   It also provides the feature to set the width of a widget to occupy 2
>   columns on the screen, while maintaining the set column layout for other
>   widgets. This allows widgets that have more details and be more readable and
>   accessible.

>   If a widget is set to occupy two columns, it is called a Cross Column
>   Widget.

>   To enable cross column widgets, the following items must be configured:

-   widget.xml of the relevant widget.

-   TWO_COLUMNS_WIDGET system parameter

-   Widget JSP and JS files

    -   [CEWeb.war]:\\widgets\\framework\\layouts\\column3\\layout.jsp

    -   [CEWeb.war]:\\widgets\\framework\\layouts\\column3\\column3.css

    -   [CEWeb.war]:\\widgets\\framework\\personalize\\Personalize.js

    -   [CEWeb.war]:\\widgets\\framework\\personalize\\CSWidget.js

        **![](media/dbcc08f02d55bf00c6d727f95e13c20c.png)NOTE:** For lower CE
        versions, a maximum of 3 widget columns is supported.

Widget.xml File

To enable cross column widgets, the acrossColumn attribute must be modified or
added to the corresponding widget.xml file of the relevant widget.

>   **![](media/dbcc08f02d55bf00c6d727f95e13c20c.png)NOTE:** Once the value of
>   the acrossColumn attribute is set to Y and the widget is added to the cross
>   column section, it may not be reverted back to a normal widget until the
>   acrossColumn attribute is set to N and the application server is restarted.

>   Example:

>   \<iw:itemSet id="attributes"\>

>   \<iw:item id="acrossColumn" alias="acrossColumn" lang="" readOnly="false"
>   value="Y"/\>

>   \</iw:itemSet\>

TWO_COLUMNS_WIDGET System Parameter

This parameter is used to define whether the width of a widget is to be
automatically adjusted or to be retained to its default setting.

If the value of this parameter is set to TRUE, the system automatically adjusts
the width of each column to occupy 50% of the browser page width. This applies
if the widgets are set to occupy only two columns on the browser page.

If the value of this parameter is set to FALSE, the width of each column remains
at 33% of the browser page width, regardless if the defined layout is two or
three columns.

Layout.jsp

The layout.jsp file is used to define the columns on the landing page where
widgets are to be arranged.

This is also used to define the location of cross column section. Different sets
of codes are provided to display the cross column section either on the left
side or right side of the page.

>   ![](media/484376c5e28e6fece5e429cfb2f6d578.gif)NOTE: Refer to the [Setting
>   Widget Columns](#Setting_Widget_Columns) discussion in Chapter 23 for more
>   information on widget column settings.

To display the cross column section on the right side of the page for 3 column
widget setting, the layout.jsp file must have the following contents:

Column3.css

The column3.css file contains Cascading Style Sheets (CSS) codes that are used
to define the format and layout of the html elements that are defined in the
layout.jsp file.

To enable cross column widgets, this file must have the following contents:

| .widgetMain {  background: none repeat scroll 0 0 \#FFFFFF;  border: 0 none;  padding: 10px 0 0;  min-height: 600px;  position: relative;  height:auto !important;  display: inline-block;  width:100%; } .widgetMain  .csLayoutContainers{  overflow: visible;  padding: 0;  display: inline-block;  width: 100%; } .widgetMain .csLayoutContainers  .component-container {  float: left;  display: inline;  position: relative;  box-sizing:border-box; } .widgetMain .csLayoutContainers  .component-container.csLayoutColumn1, .component-container.csLayoutColumn4{  padding-left: 5px; } /\*.widgetMain .csLayoutContainers  .layoutCol, .widgetMain .csLayoutContainers  .layoutColM {  width: 33%;  min-height: 600px;  height:auto ; }\*/ \#loading.tb.lt{  display: none;  } \#loading .msgp .bar .rate.ltr{  width: 33%;  } .widgetMain .csLayoutContainers .component-container.csLayoutColumn1, .component-container.csLayoutColumn2{  width: 50%;  min-height: 600px;  height:auto; } .widgetMain .csLayoutContainers .component-container.csLayoutColumn3{  width: 33%;  min-height: 600px;  height:auto; } .widgetMain .csLayoutContainers  .layoutCol4 {  width: 100%;  min-height: 120px;  height:auto;  border:1px dashed \#C0C0C0; } .line{  float:left;  display: inline;  width:66%; } .line2{  float:left;  display:block;  width:100%; } |

CSWidget.js

>   The CSWidget.js file contains JavaScript codes that handle the behavior of
>   widgets.

>   To enable cross column widgets, the following items must be added to the
>   Constants block:

-   layoutCols1:".twoColumn"

-   layoutCols2:".oneColumn"

>   Example:

| Constants:{  navTabRoot:".widgetNavTabs",  layoutRoot:".widgetMain",  layoutBody:".csLayoutContainers",  layoutCols:".component-container",  //CEV2-04-01-12 harry.wang s  layoutCols1:".twoColumn",  layoutCols2:".oneColumn",  //CEV2-04-01-12 harry.wang e  widgetRoot:".component-control",  widgetHead:".decoration-titlebar",  widgetBody:".csWidgetBody",  widgetFoot:".decoration-toolbar",  actMenuIcon:".cs-mode-menu",  placeholder:"widget-placeholder",  widgetsPool:".widgetsPool",  settingBar:".settingBar",  initMode:"view",  personalize:false,  personalizeBtn:".personalizeBtn",  TabSource:"../widgets/framework/scripts/Tabs.js",  ActionMenuSource:"../widgets/framework/scripts/WidgetActionMenu.js",  lang:null,  SUPPORTED_IE:["6.0","7.0","8.0","9.0","10.0"]  }  } }); |

>   Removing Widgets

>   To remove a widget from the relevant tab on the landing page:

| **Do the following . . .** |
|----------------------------|

| 1. Log on to the CE system as an Operator user.  The CE landing page is displayed.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             |   | ![](media/0efa3c8667c0e7600e4e9f31ec0565f7.png) |
|----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|---|-------------------------------------------------|
|                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                |   |                                                 |
| 2. Click on the Personalize link.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              |   | ![](media/4015874b332625027bccb306518cbe32.png) |
|                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                |   |                                                 |
| 3. The Personalize page is displayed. On the left section is the Product Services panel. This lists all the available widget (or widget instances). The right section displays the available tabs and their corresponding widget instances. Click on the tab that contains the widget instance to be removed.   **EXAMPLE:** The Main Menu, Welcome, and Quick Access widgets have been added to the Home tab. |   | ![](media/b348456778d55d6ce80da75cc3c24f1a.png) |
|                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                |   |                                                 |
| 4. Each widget instance is provided with a menu.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               |   | ![](media/899b04c40d1a1cf8265eea20defc8297.png) |
|                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                |   |                                                 |
| Open this menu and click on the Remove option to delete the widget instance.   **EXAMPLE:** The Quick Access widget is to be removed from the Home tab.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        |   | ![](media/2209cfefea165be0260d83293de89ed0.png) |
|                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                |   |                                                 |
| 5. The widget instance has now been deleted. Click on the Save Changes button.  **NOTE:** The Save and Discard links can be used to save and discard changes or actions made.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  |   | ![](media/c2e2a2d5cf8e6d477d015a654ba999b1.png) |
|                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                |   |                                                 |
| 6. A confirmation message is displayed. Click on the Done button.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              |   | ![](media/8ff123c2c373494aa8ed1f3ecab0efb2.png) |
|                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                |   |                                                 |
| 7. The system returns to the landing page. >   Adding Tabs on the Landing Page

>   A tab may contain several widgets. It may take some time, however, to load
>   the page if a tab contains too many widgets. Multiple tabs, each containing
>   a set of widgets, enable the system to load all the screen elements more
>   efficiently.

>   The system provides a default tab: Home. To add a tab on the landing page:

| **Do the following . . .** |

General Widget Parameter Settings

All widget types require a profile definition. This profile definition can also
be used for creating another widget of the same primary attributes.

With some widgets, additional or advanced settings are required.

>   **![](media/dbcc08f02d55bf00c6d727f95e13c20c.png)NOTE:** The specific
>   settings that apply to a particular widget type are discussed in the chapter
>   dedicated to that widget.

>   Widget Profile Settings

>   The Widget profile is defined through the Widget Maintain function.

>   Configuration

>   Define the following details in the Widget Profile window.

| ![](media/a77f0cf2172aff53ccf42087892470b7.png) |
|-------------------------------------------------|

Figure 9. 7 Widget Profile Window

| **Field** |   | **Field Description** |
|-----------|---|-----------------------|

| **Widget Name** |   | Specify the unique key of the widget. In configuring any of the 12 basic CE widgets, the following exact names must be followed: Calculator CalendarEvents CriteriaSearch Dashboard ExchangeRate MainMenu Notification QuickAccess RecentFunction Summary UploadMessage WelcomeBox  **NOTE:**  A widget profile that is based on any of the 12 CE standard widgets can be created. This functionality is done through the Extend Definition File option. Refer to the [Widget Definition File Extension](#WidgetDefinitionFileExt) discussion in this chapter for more details.                                                                                                                                                                 |
|-----------------|---|-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
|                 |   |                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 |
| **Description** |   | Provide the description of the widget.  This becomes the default name of the widget in the Frame Work list section in the Widget Setting tab of the Widget Maintain function window.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            |
|                 |   |                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 |
| **Widget Type** |   | This is *currently not used*. Nonetheless, make sure that the Global option is selected.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        |
|                 |   |                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 |
| **Version**     |   | Specify the version of the widget. This is used for information and tracking purposes in case the widget is updated in the future.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              |
|                 |   |                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 |
| **System Role** |   | Assign the user role for the widget: select the kinds of users to which the widget is to be made available. The user roles are: Super Officer Bank Administrator Bank Operator Customer Administrator Customer Operator  At least one user role must be selected. Otherwise, it cannot be used by any user once this setting is synchronized with the database. Upon synchronization (through the Synchronize to DB button), the widget details defined here are going to override the original settings in the database.    **NOTE:**  These roles are stored in the SEC_WIDGET_RIGHTS table. The values are 0, for Super Officer; 1 for Customer Administrator; 2, for Customer Operator; 3 for Bank Administrator; and 4, for Bank Operator. |
|                 |   |                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 |
| **Status**      |   | This indicates whether or not the widget can be used. Select the Active option.  **NOTE:** The Inactive option is *currently not used.*                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         |

>   Other Widget Settings

Widget Action Popup Setting

The WIDGET_ACTION_POPUP security parameter is used to control whether the system
pops up a new window when a widget hyperlink or button is clicked. The following
is an example of how the system displays the relevant screen when this this
parameter is set to TRUE.

**EXAMPLE:**

In the Dashboard widget, click on the View Import LC link. The View Import LC
screen is displayed on a popup window:

>   ![](media/7c90b2ff4b817ba95718b2d2960bd985.png)

In the Criteria Search widget, select the Import Letters of Credit – Authorise
Transaction option from the Search For dropdown field and click on the Search
button. The Authorise Transaction screen is displayed on a popup window:

>   ![](media/f043e8823bcc5e5ecbb9666744abd420.png)

RTL Settings

The RTL security parameter is used to change how widgets, transaction functions,
and error messages are displayed on the CE page: certain elements are
re-arranged from right to left.

For widgets –

-   The hyperlinks follow this order – Sign Out, Help, Personalize, [User Name]
    – instead of: [User Name], Personalize, Help, and Sign Out.

-   The Title and Description elements, when personalizing a widget, are
    right-aligned.

-   The functions from these widgets are right-aligned: Main Menu and its Search
    tool, Quick Access, and Recent Functions.

-   The descriptions are displayed on the right: Upload Message, Welcome,
    Criteria Search,

-   Calendar Events: The weekends and weekdays are displayed from right to left.

-   The elements are reversed: Exchange Rate (rates first, then the currencies),
    Summary, Notice.

For transaction functions:

-   The tabs and buttons are displayed in reversed order.

-   The field descriptions are displayed on the right.

For error messages:

-   The error messages are right-aligned.

To enable this right-to-left style for widgets:

| **Do the following . . .** |
|----------------------------|

| 1. As a Super Administrator user, run the System Parameters function from the Parameter Manage function group of the CE Utility.                                                                                                                                                                                                                               |   | ![](media/dc06596f83b56caf99a27e9cbde51628.png) |
|----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|---|-------------------------------------------------|
|                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                |   |                                                 |
| 2. Set the RTL system parameter value to: dir=’rtl’.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           |   | ![](media/dfc1d45e65018c03fbb97e680c11ebba.png) |
|                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                |   |                                                 |
| 3. As an Operator user, run the XML Generator function from the Maintenance function group.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    |   | ![](media/b8f18dd7421b13c573b9f25f61b0b6d6.png) |

Specific Widget Settings

Some widget types require:

-   Advanced settings in the Widget Maintain function in the CE Utility

-   Settings in another CE Utility function (e.g., Notification function)

-   Prerequisite products and functions (e.g., Notification View and Label
    products)

These specific settings that apply only to particular widget types are discussed
in their respective chapters.

The Calendar Events Widget

-   Overview

-   Parameter SEttings

-   Browser Settings

Overview

The Calendar Events widget, aside from showing basic calendar information,
provides the following functionalities:

-   Weekends and holidays are highlighted for easy identification.

-   Dates with events are appropriately marked with flags.

-   The types of events to be utilized by the widget can be defined.

-   Notes can be recorded for specific dates.

-   Functions can be started – and the relevant record viewed or processed –
    through the given events. These events pertain to specific transaction dates
    (e.g., LC expiry dates).

The availability of events to the end-user is FAP-controlled: the user must have
rights to the related function in order to view and access the events.

>   Widget](#UsingtheCalendarEvtsWidget)
